Stephen Swift wrote:

>You guys have really done an excellent job.  I never expected a 
>potential integer based neural approach to be developed - let alone 
>tested - when I raised the double vs single float question.
>  
>
Well I've been thinking about the idea for a while, I just never got 
round to developing it.

>What code base would you recommend starting with to performance 
>profile a NEAT engine on a Blackfin?  Note the Blackfin supports a 32 
>bit multiply instruction but no divide.  The 32 bit mulitply is a 
>multi-clock instruction.  Preliminary testing yields little 
>difference in timing between 16 bit and 32 bit multiples for simple 
>operations.
>  
>
As it happens the network code I wrote doesn't use division, I seem to 
remember Ian saying that division was quite an expensive operation so I 
ensured that all divisions in the code were powers of 2 which can be 
done with the far cheaper/faster shift-right operation.

I'm not sure you really need to run an actual NEAT engine on the 
blackfin, you probably want to evolve a network on a desktop PC and then 
transfer the resulting network onto the Blackfin for actual operational 
use. To do this you just need to port the neural net code into C++ or 
whatever you're using - which should be straightforward, since there's 
very little actual code.

Another important point that I was reminded of recently is that my 
FastConcurrent network class is really a general purpose neural net that 
activates each neuron in distinct timesteps, that is, at each timestep 
every single neuron calculates it's output signal for the next timestep. 
This approach allows us to support recursive connections while keeping 
the code simple. There are however, faster ways of activating a network, 
especially if you will be working with feed-forward only nets. I think 
Derek and Philip (on this list) are using an alternative approach, and I 
understand Emyr is looking into this area too. Even so, the techniques 
described in the write-up are still applicable, it's just you might be 
able to get even beter performance with a different activation technique 
than the one I'm using.

Colin
